body.head: Encoding Manual for Digital Lacy
body.p: The Digital Lacy project makes available in TEI-XML format a corpus of over 100 plays transcribed from Lacy's Acting Edition of plays (1845-1878). This document provides details and explanation of the XML encoding and editorial practices followed.

The corpus as a whole is represented by a single teiCorpus element, which embeds a sequence of TEI elements. Each play is represented by a single TEI element with an xml:id value used to identify it throughout the archive. This identifier consists of the letter L (for Lacy) and four digits, corresponding with the number originally allocated to this play in the published series. In the few cases where a second play exists using the same number, its identifier is suffixed with the letter R (for replaced). This Lacy identifier (such as "L0234") is also used to name the XML file containing the play.

Each TEI element is organised in the same way, following standard TEI practice, and using standard TEI elements. It has two constituents: a teiHeader and a text. The teiHeader provides metadata identifying and documenting the play: see further section 2 below. The play itself is represented by a text element.

div.head: The teiHeader
div.p: The function of the TEI Header is to provide metadata describing the resource. It has the usual TEI structure, a fileDescription....

div.head: The text
div.p: The text element contains an accurate transcription of the textual content of the play, as printed in the edition used as source. The transcription excludes supporting matter such as covers or advertising pages, but is otherwise complete, including page breaks, title pages, prefatory remarks, appendixes, etc. The transcription aims to represent correctly all of the printed text and to indicate its intended function (as a title, speech, stage direction etc.); it does not however aim to represent directly its visual appearance, although each section of transcription may be linked to a page image by means of the pb element representing a page break in the document used as copy text. The typographic exuberance often found in title pages and programme notes is not encoded at all, and the particular form of visual salience used to signal (for example) a speech prefix or a character name in a stage direction is not recorded.
The text element may have three components: a front, a body,. and an optional back

div.head: Front matter
div.p:
The front matter of a play consists of its title page (optionally preceded by a frontispiece), and whatever else precedes the heading of the first act or the start of the play. These structural components are represented using one or more of the following elements:
titlePage
performance and castList
div

div.head: Title Page
div.p: The titlePage element contains a transcription of the words of the title page, disregarding its formatting. It typically contains one or more titlePart elements containing a title, subtitle, etc., followed by a byline element optionally containing the name of the author/s tagged with docAuthor and a list of other works by the same author, each tagged with title. At the end of the page, the words of the imprint are tagged with docImprint.

A simple title page

In Lacy XML we make no attempt to capture typographic features of the original: case is normalised, and font changes ignored. This example is encoded like this:
Novelty Fair; or, Hints for 1851. An Exceedingly Premature, And Thoroughly Apropos Revue. By the Authors of Valentine and Orson, Whittington and his Cat, Cinderella, &c, &c., &c. T. H. Lacy, 17, Wellington Street, Strand, London.

div.head: The body of a play text
div.p:
The body of a play text is made up of the following components:
Acts and Scenes
Speeches
Stage directions
Musical numbers

div.head: Stage directions
div.p: Stage directions may appear in various contexts and have different functions. Most plays begin with a lengthy stage direction describing the scene, which is distinct from stage directions describing action on the stage. A stage direction may appear within the speech of a character, usually if it is short and indicates something about the way the actor is delivering their lines (e.g. 'aside', 'laughing'), or relating to their movement only (e.g. 'crossing to U.R.', 'Exit'). Stage directions may also appear between speeches, usually describing the entrance or exit of multiple characters, or a large amount of stage business. In Lacy texts, it is customary to indicate an actor's position on stage by means of an abbreviation such as 'L.' (for stage left), or a sequence of abbreviations referencing not just the side of the stage but also the depth, sometimes expresed in terms of the "grooves" in which stage scenery is set, '1' being the groove nearest the audience,; sometimes less exactly using codes such as 'U' (for upstage, i.e. away from the audience). The code 'C' stands for 'centre'; the code D for 'door'; 'L. 1. E.' (stage left, first groove, entrance)
